{{Infobox College Soccer Team |name = Florida Gators soccer |logo = Florida Gators logo.svg |logo_size = 175 |university = University of Florida |conference = Southeastern Conference |conference_short = SEC |division = |city = Gainesville |stateabb = FL |state = Florida |coach = [[Becky Burleigh]] |tenure = 17th |stadium = [[James G. Pressly Stadium]] |capacity = 4,500 |nickname = [[Florida Gators]] |color1 = Blue |color2 = Orange |color3 = |fontcolor = FF4A00 |hex1 = 0021A5 |hex2 = FF4A00 |hex3 = |NCAAchampion = 1998 |NCAArunnerup = |NCAAtourneys = 1996, 1997, 1998, 1999, 2000, 2001, 2003, 2004, 2005, 2006, 2007, 2008, 2009, 2010 |conference_tournament = 1996, 1997, 1998, 1999, 2000, 2001, 2004, 2007, 2010 |conference_season = 1996, 1997, 1998, 1999, 2000, 2001, 2004, 2007, 2008, 2009, 2010 }} The '''Florida Gators women's soccer''' team represents the [[University of Florida]] in the sport of college [[association football|soccer]]. The Gators compete in [[Division I (NCAA)|Division I]] of the [[National Collegiate Athletics Association]] (NCAA) and the [[Southeastern Conference]] (SEC). They play their home games in [[James G. Pressly Stadium]] on the university's [[Gainesville, Florida]] campus, and are currently led by head coach [[Becky Burleigh]]. In the sixteen-year history of the Gators' soccer program, they have won eleven SEC championships and one NCAA national championship.
== History ==
[[Becky Burleigh]] was named the first head coach of the start-up Florida Gators soccer program on June 28, 1994, and has served as the only head coach in the program's fifteen-season history.<ref name=gatorzoneyearbyyear>''2008 Florida Gators Soccer Media Guide'', [http://www.gatorzone.com/soccer/media/2008/pdf/records/year_by_year.pdf Year-by-Year Results], University Athletic Association, Gainesville, Florida (2008). Retrieved July 17, 2009.</ref> Since the Gators' began play in the fall of 1995, the team has compiled a record of 264–70–23 and a winning percentage of 0.7717, and Burleigh's Gators teams have qualified for the NCAA Tournament thirteen of the last fifteen seasons.<ref name=gatorzoneyearbyyear/>
In 1998, in the Gators soccer program's fourth year of existence, the Gators won their first NCAA national title by defeating the defending national champion [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill|North Carolina]] Tar Heels 1–0 in the final game of the tournament.<ref name=pdooley60409>Pat Dooley, "[http://www.gainesville.com/article/20090620/ARTICLES/906049953/1136/sports?Title=Top-25-Gator-teams-5-1998-Women-s-soccer Top 25 Gator teams: #5 1998 Women's soccer]," ''Gainesville Sun'' (June 4, 2009). Retrieved July 15, 2009.</ref> The 1998 Gators finished 26–1, having lost their only match to the same North Carolina team that the Gators defeated in the NCAA championship final.<ref name=pdooley60409/> Players from the Gators' 1998 national championship team included All-Americans Erin Baxter, [[Danielle Fotopoulos]] and [[Heather Mitts]].<ref name=pdooley60409/>
In addition to their 1998 national championship season, the Gators have previously advanced to the NCAA tournament semi-final once (2001), the quarter-finals twice (1996, 2003), and the round of sixteen three times (2006, 2007, 2008).<ref name=gatorzone2009schedule>GatorZone.com, Soccer, [http://www.gatorzone.com/sched.php?sport=socce 2009 Schedule]. Retrieved December 13, 2009.</ref>
The Gators play in the Eastern Division of the Southeastern Conference.<ref>''See, generally'', SECSports.com, [http://www.secsports.com/index.php?s=&url_channel_id=14&change_well_id=1 Soccer]. Retrieved July 15, 2009.</ref> In conference play, the Gators teams have won ten SEC championships, and eight SEC tournament titles, leading all other SEC teams since the Florida soccer team began play in 1995.<ref>SECSports.com, Soccer, [http://www.secsports.com/doc_lib/wsoc_recordbook.pdf SEC Soccer Record Book]. Retrieved July 15, 2009.</ref> Most recently, the Gators won the SEC championship (regular season) again in 2010, and qualified for the NCAA women's soccer tournament for the eighth consecutive year. In 2009, the Gators advanced to the second round of the NCAA tournament before losing to [[Oregon State University|Oregon State]].<ref>GatorZone, Soccer, NCAA 2008 Soccer Championship, [http://www.gatorzone.com/soccer/tour/ncaa/2009/ First, Second & Third Round Bracket]. Retrieved December 13, 2009.</ref> The Gators finished their 2009 season 8–1–2 in the SEC, and 16–6–2 overall.<ref name=gatorzone2009schedule/>
== All-Americans, Olympians and World Cup players ==
In its fifteen seasons of play, the Florida soccer program has produced sixteen first-team [[All-American]] selections, including Ameera Abdullah, Erin Baxter, Keisha Bell, Stacy Bishop, [[Melanie Booth]], Meredith Flaherty, [[Danielle Fotopoulos]], Stephanie Freeman, Lauren Hyde, Erin Gilhart, [[Heather Mitts]], Adrienne Moreira, [[Danielle Murphy]], Andi Sellers, [[Abby Wambach]] and Sarah Yohe.<ref>GatorZone.com, Soccer, 2008 Soccer Media Guide, [http://www.gatorzone.com/soccer/media/2008/pdf/honors/all_americans.pdf Gator All-Americans]. Retrieved July 16, 2009.</ref>
Former All-American Danielle Fotopoulos was a member of the [[United States women's national soccer team|U.S. National Team]] from 1996 to 2005), and played for the American [[FIFA Women's World Cup]] championship team in ([[1999 FIFA Women's World Cup|1999]]).
Two former Gator All-Americans, Abby Wambach and Heather Mitts, were members of the U.S. national team that won the [[gold medal]] in women's soccer at the [[2004 Summer Olympics]] in [[Athens, Greece]],<ref>Official Site of Abby Wambach, [http://www.abbywambach.com/wambach/about Bio]. Retrieved July 20, 2009.</ref><ref name=heathermittsabout>Heather Mitts: The Official Website, [http://www.heathermitts.com/about.htm About]. Retrieved July 20, 2009.</ref> and Mitts returned to the U.S. team that again won the gold medal at the [[2008 Summer Olympics]] in [[Beijing, China]].<ref name=heathermittsabout/> Both Wambach and Mitts were members of the U.S. runner-up team in the FIFA Women's World Cup team in ([[2011 FIFA Women's World Cup|2011]]). Wambach was also a member of the U.S. World Cup team in ([[2003 FIFA Women's World Cup|2003]]) and ([[2007 FIFA Women's World Cup|2007]]).
Former All-American Melanie Booth has been a member of the [[Canada women's national soccer team|Canada National Team]] since 2001, and was a member of Canada's FIFA Women's World Cup team in ([[2007 FIFA Women's World Cup|2007]]).
Former Gator Danielle Murphy played for the [[England women's national football team|England National Team]] from 1998 to 2003, and was the youngest-ever member of England's FIFA Women's World Cup team.
== Coaching staff ==
Becky Burleigh became the first and only head coach of the Florida Gators soccer program on June 28, 1994. Since then, she has compiled a record of 264–70–23 in fifteen seasons as the Gators' head coach.<ref name=gatorzoneyearbyyear/> Prior to coaching at Florida, Burleigh was the head coach at [[Berry College]], where her Lady Fury teams won two [[National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics|NAIA]] national championships.<ref name=gatorzoneburleighbio>GatorZone.com, Soccer, Coaching & Support Staff, [http://www.gatorzone.com/soccer/coaches.php?coach=burleigh.html Becky Burleigh Biography]. Retrieved July 15, 2009.</ref> At Florida and Berry, Burleigh has compiled an overall record of 346–93–29, with a winning percentage of 0.7703.<ref name=gatorzoneburleighbio/> She ranks fourth in total number of wins, and fifth in winning percentage, among all active Division I women's soccer coaches.<ref name=gatorzoneburleighbio/>
[[Image:Abby Wambach.jpg|thumb|left|230px|[[Abby Wambach]], first-team All-SEC (1998–2001), first-team All-American (1999, 2001), all-time Gators scoring leader.]]
Victor Campbell has served as the Gators' associate head coach for the past six seasons, after serving as an assistant coach for the previous eight seasons.<ref name=gatorzonecampbellbio>GatorZone.com, Soccer, Coaching & Support Staff, [http://www.gatorzone.com/soccer/coaches.php?coach=campbell.html Victor Campbell Biography]. Retrieved July 17, 2009.</ref> He primarily coaches the forwards and attacking midfielders.<ref name=gatorzonecampbellbio/> Campbell previously was an assistant at [[Methodist University|Methodist College]] for seven seasons.<ref name=gatorzonecampbellbio/>
Alan Kirkup is the Gators' assistant coach, joining the team after having previously been the head coach for [[Southern Methodist University]], the [[University of Maryland, College Park|University of Maryland]] and the [[University of Arkansas]].<ref name=gatorzonekirupbio>GatorZone.com, Soccer, Coaching & Support Staff, [http://www.gatorzone.com/soccer/coaches.php?coach=kirkup.html Alan Kirkup Biography]. Retrieved July 17, 2009.</ref> Before he began his U.S. collegiate coaching career, Kirkup was a professional soccer player for [[Manchester United F.C.|Manchester United Football Club]].<ref name=gatorzonekirupbio/>
== James G. Pressly Stadium ==
The Florida Gators soccer team plays its home games in [[James G. Pressly Stadium]].<ref name=gatorzonefacilities>GatorZone.com, Facilities, [http://gatorzone.com/facilities/?venue=percy&sport=socce James G. Pressly Stadium]. Retrieved July 16, 2009.</ref> Pressly Stadium is a dual-purpose facility serving as home to the soccer team and the men's and women's outdoor track & field teams.<ref name=gatorzonefacilities/> It is a lighted stadium and has a seating capacity of approximately 4,500.<ref name=gatorzonefacilities/> The stadium is named for James G. Pressly, a 1972 alumnus of the [[University of Florida College of Law]], who made a generous contribution to have the facility upgraded for Division I play.<ref name=gatorzonefacilities/>
The Gators soccer team also has the exclusive use of a new soccer practice field that was completed as part of the [[Florida Gators women's lacrosse|Florida Lacrosse Facility]] in 2009.<ref name=gatorzonefacilities/>
